com.pump.geom

Class AreaX

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.geom.AreaX
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.Shape, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class AreaX
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.awt.Shape, java.lang.Cloneable
    This class is a direct branch from the java.awt.geom.Area.

    An AreaX object stores and manipulates a resolution-independent description of an enclosed area of 2-dimensional space. AreaX objects can be transformed and can perform various Constructive Area Geometry (CAG) operations when combined with other AreaX objects. The CAG operations include area addition, subtraction, intersection, and exclusive or. See the linked method documentation for examples of the various operations.

    The AreaX class implements the Shape interface and provides full support for all of its hit-testing and path iteration facilities, but an AreaX is more specific than a generalized path in a number of ways:

    • Only closed paths and sub-paths are stored. AreaX objects constructed from unclosed paths are implicitly closed during construction as if those paths had been filled by the Graphics2D.fill method.
    • The interiors of the individual stored sub-paths are all non-empty and non-overlapping. Paths are decomposed during construction into separate component non-overlapping parts, empty pieces of the path are discarded, and then these non-empty and non-overlapping properties are maintained through all subsequent CAG operations. Outlines of different component sub-paths may touch each other, as long as they do not cross so that their enclosed areas overlap.
    • The geometry of the path describing the outline of the AreaX resembles the path from which it was constructed only in that it describes the same enclosed 2-dimensional area, but may use entirely different types and ordering of the path segments to do so.
    Interesting issues which are not always obvious when using the AreaX include:
    • Creating an AreaX from an unclosed (open) Shape results in a closed outline in the AreaX object.
    • Creating an AreaX from a Shape which encloses no area (even when "closed") produces an empty AreaX. A common example of this issue is that producing an AreaX from a line will be empty since the line encloses no area. An empty AreaX will iterate no geometry in its PathIterator objects.
    • A self-intersecting Shape may be split into two (or more) sub-paths each enclosing one of the non-intersecting portions of the original path.
    • An AreaX may take more path segments to describe the same geometry even when the original outline is simple and obvious. The analysis that the AreaX class must perform on the path may not reflect the same concepts of "simple and obvious" as a human being perceives.

    What is stated above is directly copied from the java.awt.geom.Area javadocs. Below are notes specifically related to the AreaX class:

    The AreaX class is intended to achieve exactly the same visual results as the Area class. However several possible optimizations have been carefully implemented to reach those results faster.

    The most customizable change is the implementation of the AreaXRules object. Developers are encouraged to subclass this object and experiment with it. (And if they make improvements: email them to me to include in this project!)

    Each AreaX object has a reference to a rules object that can be changed by calling: myArea.setRules(). However you can also change the default rules for all future AreaX objects by calling: UIManager.put("AreaX.rules", myRules).

    See Also:
    https://javagraphics.java.net/areax/

      • AreaX

      • AreaX

        public AreaX(java.awt.Shape s)
        The AreaX class creates an area geometry from the specified Shape object. The geometry is explicitly closed, if the Shape is not already closed. The fill rule (even-odd or winding) specified by the geometry of the Shape is used to determine the resulting enclosed area.
        Parameters:
        s - the Shape from which the area is constructed.

        If this is an AreaX, then this constructor forces any pending operations to be performed.

        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if s is null

      • processQueue

        public void processQueue()
        This immediately executes all pending operations on this AreaX. It should not be necessary for other objects to need to call this method, except to manager the time/cost of execution.

      • getBody

        public AreaXBody getBody()
        This returns the AreaXBody that currently expressed the data in this AreaX. This object will constantly be replaced as new operations are performed.

        This forces any pending operations to be performed.

      • add

        public void add(java.awt.Shape rhs)
        Adds the shape of the specified Shape to the shape of this AreaX. The resulting shape of this AreaX will include the union of both shapes, or all areas that were contained in either this or the specified AreaX. 
             // Example:
     Area a1 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 0,8]);
     Area a2 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 8,8]);
     a1.add(a2);

        a1(before)     +         a2         =     a1(after)

     ################     ################     ################
     ##############         ##############     ################
     ############             ############     ################
     ##########                 ##########     ################
     ########                     ########     ################
     ######                         ######     ######    ######
     ####                             ####     ####        ####
     ##                                 ##     ##            ##

        This call does not immediately execute. It adds this operation to a queue of operations that are processed as required.

        Parameters:
        rhs - the Shape to be added to the current shape
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if rhs is null

      • getRelationship

        public int getRelationship(java.awt.geom.AffineTransform lhsTransform,
                           java.awt.Shape shape,
                           java.awt.geom.AffineTransform transform)
        Returns one of the relationship constants to indicate the relationship between this shape and the argument (with the optional transform).
        Parameters:
        lhsTransform - the optional transform to apply to this operand.
        shape -
        transform - an optional transform to apply to the argument.
        Returns:
        one of the 4 relationship constants: RELATIONSHIP_LHS_CONTAINS, RELATIONSHIP_RHS_CONTAINS, RELATIONSHIP_NONE, or RELATIONSHIP_COMPLEX.

        public void executeAdd(AreaX rhs)
        Adds the shape of the specified AreaX to the shape of this AreaX. The resulting shape of this AreaX will include the union of both shapes, or all areas that were contained in either this or the specified AreaX. 
             // Example:
     Area a1 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 0,8]);
     Area a2 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 8,8]);
     a1.add(a2);

      • subtract

        public void subtract(java.awt.Shape rhs)

             // Example:
     Area a1 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 0,8]);
     Area a2 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 8,8]);

      • intersect

        public void intersect(java.awt.Shape rhs)
        Sets the shape of this AreaX to the intersection of its current shape and the shape of the specified Shape. The resulting shape of this AreaX will include only areas that were contained in both this AreaX and also in the specified AreaX. 
             // Example:
     Area a1 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 0,8]);
     Area a2 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 8,8]);
     a1.intersect(a2);

      a1(before)   intersect     a2         =     a1(after)

      • exclusiveOr

        public void exclusiveOr(java.awt.Shape rhs)
        Sets the shape of this AreaX to be the combined area of its current shape and the shape of the specified Shape, minus their intersection. The resulting shape of this AreaX will include only areas that were contained in either this AreaX or in the specified AreaX, but not in both. 
             // Example:
     Area a1 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 0,8]);
     Area a2 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 8,8]);
     a1.exclusiveOr(a2);

        a1(before)    xor        a2         =     a1(after)

     ################     ################
     ##############         ##############     ##            ##
     ############             ############     ####        ####
     ##########                 ##########     ######    ######
     ########                     ########     ################
     ######                         ######     ######    ######
     ####                             ####     ####        ####
     ##                                 ##     ##            ##

        This call does not immediately execute. It adds this operation to a queue of operations that are processed as required.

        Parameters:
        rhs - the AreaX to be exclusive ORed with this AreaX.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if rhs is null

      • executeExclusiveOr

        public void executeExclusiveOr(AreaX rhs)
        Sets the shape of this AreaX to be the combined area of its current shape and the shape of the specified AreaX, minus their intersection. The resulting shape of this AreaX will include only areas that were contained in either this AreaX or in the specified AreaX, but not in both. 
             // Example:
     Area a1 = new Area([triangle 0,0 => 8,0 => 0,8]);

      • isSingular

        public boolean isSingular()
        Tests whether this AreaX is comprised of a single closed subpath. This method returns true if the path contains 0 or 1 subpaths, or false if the path contains more than 1 subpath. The subpaths are counted by the number of SEG_MOVETO segments that appear in the path.

        This forces any pending operations to be performed.

        Returns:
        true if the AreaX is comprised of a single basic geometry; false otherwise.

      • getBounds2D

        public java.awt.geom.Rectangle2D getBounds2D()
        Returns a high precision bounding Rectangle2D that completely encloses this AreaX.

        The Area class will attempt to return the tightest bounding box possible for the Shape. The bounding box will not be padded to include the control points of curves in the outline of the Shape, but should tightly fit the actual geometry of the outline itself.

        This forces any pending operations to be performed.

        Specified by:
        getBounds2D in interface java.awt.Shape
        Returns:
        the bounding Rectangle2D for the AreaX.

      • getBounds

        public java.awt.Rectangle getBounds()
        Returns a bounding Rectangle that completely encloses this AreaX.

        The Area class will attempt to return the tightest bounding box possible for the Shape. The bounding box will not be padded to include the control points of curves in the outline of the Shape, but should tightly fit the actual geometry of the outline itself. Since the returned object represents the bounding box with integers, the bounding box can only be as tight as the nearest integer coordinates that encompass the geometry of the Shape.

        This forces any pending operations to be performed.

        Specified by:
        getBounds in interface java.awt.Shape
        Returns:
        the bounding Rectangle for the AreaX.

      • transform

        public void transform(java.awt.geom.AffineTransform t)
        Transforms the geometry of this AreaX using the specified AffineTransform. The geometry is transformed in place, which permanently changes the enclosed area defined by this object.

        This forces any pending operations to be performed.

        Parameters:
        t - the transformation used to transform the area
        Throws:

      • getPathIterator

        public java.awt.geom.PathIterator getPathIterator(java.awt.geom.AffineTransform at)
        Creates a PathIterator for the outline of this AreaX object. This AreaX object is unchanged.

        This forces any pending operations to be performed.

        Specified by:
        getPathIterator in interface java.awt.Shape
        Parameters:
        at - an optional AffineTransform to be applied to the coordinates as they are returned in the iteration, or null if untransformed coordinates are desired
        Returns:
        the PathIterator object that returns the geometry of the outline of this AreaX, one segment at a time.

      • getPathIterator

        public java.awt.geom.PathIterator getPathIterator(java.awt.geom.AffineTransform at,
                                                  double flatness)
        Creates a PathIterator for the flattened outline of this AreaX object. Only uncurved path segments represented by the SEG_MOVETO, SEG_LINETO, and SEG_CLOSE point types are returned by the iterator. This AreaX object is unchanged.
        Specified by:
        getPathIterator in interface java.awt.Shape
        Parameters:
        at - an optional AffineTransform to be applied to the coordinates as they are returned in the iteration, or null if untransformed coordinates are desired
        flatness - the maximum amount that the control points for a given curve can vary from colinear before a subdivided curve is replaced by a straight line connecting the end points
        Returns:
        the PathIterator object that returns the geometry of the outline of this AreaX, one segment at a time.
